sect2.title: Accessibility
sect2.para: Support for people with disabilities has been a key focus for GNOME, so successive releases have included increasing support for accessibility. GNOME &version; improves this framework, and its tools, to create a better experience for existing users, and to make the desktop available to new groups of users.

sect3.title: Keyboard Accessibility Status
sect3.para:
The new Keyboard Accessibility Status panel applet gives quick access to the Accessibility control panel, and provides visual feedback when using the sticky-keys feature. The sticky-keys feature allows people with limited mobility to press modifier keys, such as shift, in sequence instead of simultaneously.
Keyboard Indicator
The Keyboard Accessibility Status applet, showing that the Shift and Control keys have been pressed.

sect3.title: Screen Reader and Magnifier
sect3.para:
The Gnopernicus screen reader and magnifier has some new features in GNOME &version;, based on user needs.
The "watch any widget" feature allows blind user to monitor changes to any part of the user interface. For instance, blind users can track changes to a message field, while entering text in another.
The "describe my surroundings" feature gives blind users information about the context of the currently focused UI component, via speech or braile.
And when used as an onscreen magnifier, gnopernicus now gives users even more control over tracking and cursor presentation.

sect3.title: Dasher
sect3.para:
Dasher is an innovative predictive input system that should be particularly useful to people with severe disabilities. At the moment, it allows text entry, but future versions should allow complete control of the desktop. It is also useful on small devices such as PDAs, to allow more efficient text entry without a keyboard.
